Editor’s choice paper (Ferrocenylpyrazolyl)zinc(II) acetate complexes as initiators and catalysts for the ring opening polymerization of ϵ-caprolacton. Dedicated to Professor Cedric Holzapfel on the occasion of his 80th birthday; October 3, 2015. Collins Obuah a Yemanlall Lochee a Orpah Zinyemba a Johan H.L. Jordaan b Daniel P. Otto b James Darkwa a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, University of Johannesburg, Auckland Park Kingsway Campus, Auckland Park, 2006, Johannesburg, South Africa Department of Chemistry University of Johannesburg Auckland Park Kingsway Campus Auckland Park Johannesburg 2006 South Africa b Focus Area Chemical Resource Beneficiation, Catalysis and Synthesis group North-West University, Potchefstroom, 2531, South Africa Focus Area Chemical Resource Beneficiation Catalysis and Synthesis group North-West University Potchefstroom 2531 South Africa ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The reaction of Zn(OAc)2 with 3-ferrocenylpyrazol-1-ylmethylenepyridine (L1), 3-ferrocenyl-5-methylpyrazol-1-ylmethylenepyridine (L2), 3-ferrocenylpyrazol-1-ylethylamine (L3) and 3-ferrocenyl-5-pyrazol-1-ylethylamine (L4) afford the corresponding zinc complexes [Zn(CH3COO)2(L1)] (1), [Zn(CH3COO)2(L2)] (2), [Zn(CH3COO)2(L3)] (3), and [Zn(CH3COO)2(L4)] (4). These zinc complexes behave as catalysts or initiators for the ring opening polymerization of ϵ-caprolactone, depending on the nature of the ligands, to produce polymers that are capped with α,ω-dihydroxy, hydroxyl or ferrocenylpyrazolylethylamino end groups. Complexes 1 and 2 were found to act as catalysts when the [CL]/[C] ratios were varied from 100 to 800 to produce PCL with α,ω-dihydroxy and nearly the same molecular weight. Complexes 3 and 4 on the other hand act as initiators to produce a mixture of PCL that have polymers with ferrocenylpyrazolylethylamino and a hydroxyl as end groups as the major component of the mixture and minor species with α,ω-dihydroxy end group. Keywords (Ferrocenylpyrazolyl)zinc(II) acetate ϵ-Caprolactone Ring opening polymerization Catalysts Initiators 1 Introduction Aliphatic polyesters, possessing remarkable mechanical properties, biodegradability, bioabsorbability and biocompatibility, have attracted great interest in the last two decades [1]. These polymers are material that have promoted major advances in the biomedical and pharmaceutical fields for applications such as suture materials, prostheses, and controlled drug releasing devices [2]. Polycaprolactone, (PCL) is an attractive material because of its valuable properties which include high permeability, lack of toxicity to living organisms, biodegradability, ability to blend with various commercial polymers or biopolymers over a wide composition range, and a relatively long half-life [18]. Polyesters are generally prepared by the ring-opening polymerization (ROP) of the corresponding lactones; consequently a series of initiators or catalysts based on Al [3], Sn [4], Fe [5], Li [6], Y [7], lanthanides [8] have been developed to improve the ring-opening polymerization of cyclic esters which is the ‘doorway’ to accessing these polyesters. Most of these initiators or catalysts are metal alkoxides or metal carboxylates supported by different ligand systems. To date stannous 2-ethylhexanoate is the only compound that is utilised for the industrial production of biomaterials via the ring-opening polymerization process [9]. The major drawback with this tin catalyst is its toxicity; resulting in the synthesised polyesters having to undergo several purification processes in an effort to remove traces of tin in the polymer. There is, therefore, a need to develop bio-friendly initiators or catalysts. Such a development should result in reduction in cost of production since the purification process of polymers after synthesis would be less rigorous. In recent years, catalysts or initiators based on calcium [10], magnesium [11], and zinc [12] have received extensive attention because these elements can be metabolised in vivo. These metals are supported on ligands that facilitate the ring opening process. Ligand design is therefore crucial as both activity and occurrence transesterification reactions in lactone polymerization are dependent on electronic and steric bulk around the metal centre. Nitrogen donor ligands, namely Schiff’s bases [13] and β-diiminate [14], have been used extensively to modify the electrophilicity of the metal centres for ring-opening polymerization. Another group of nitrogen-donor ligands that is receiving attention are ligands with pyrazolyl functional group have been used to prepare several metal catalysts [15]. The use of pyrazolyl ligands in preparing catalysts result in highly electrophilic metal centres owing to the weaker σ-donating ability of pyrazoles; a property that is crucial in the development of ROP initiators or catalysts. Ferrocenyl-based ligands have also received extensive attention in preparing metal complexes in the recent years owing to their ease of functionalization [16]. There have been a few reports on the use of ferrocenyl-based ligands in the ring-opening polymerisation of cyclic esters [17]. The interest of having a ferrocenyl ligand emanates from having redox control on the activity. We have recently combined the attributes of pyrazoles and ferrocene to prepare a number of new late transition metal complexes that are good catalysts for a number of olefin and cyclic esters transformations [19,20]. We report a unique case where bio-friendly zinc acetate, supported on ferrocenylpyrazolyl-based ligands, act as either catalyst or initiator to produce poly(caprolactones) that have end groups dictated by the nature of the ferrocenylpyrazolyl ligand. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods Unless otherwise stated, all syntheses were carried out under nitrogen atmosphere using standard Schlenk technique. Polymerization was carried out using a 50mL parallel reactor. All organic solvents were dried and purified by distillation over standard reagents under nitrogen prior to use. Compounds L1 [19], L2 [19], L3 [20], L4 [20], 3-ferrocenylpyrazole [21], and 3-ferrocenyl-5-methylpyrazole [21] were synthesized according to literature procedures. Zinc acetate, ferrocene, ethyl formate, ethyl acetate and ϵ-caprolactone (ϵ-CL) were used as received from Sigma–Aldrich. Infrared (IR) spectra complexes were recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 equipped with a diamond ATR. Elemental analyses were performed on a Vario Elementar III microcube CHN analyzer. The mass spectrometry unit at the University of Stellenbosch performed the ESI–MS spectra on a Waters API Qualtro micro spectrophotometer. NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker 400MHz instrument (1H at 400MHz and 13C{1H} at 100MHz). The chemical shifts are reported in δ (ppm) and referenced to the residual proton and carbon signals 7.24ppm and 77.0ppm, respectively, of CDCl3 NMR solvent. MALDI spectral data were collected with a Bruker AutoFLEX III Smartbeam TOF/TOF Mass spectrometer. The instrument was operated in positive ion mode using an m/z range of 500–10,000. The voltages of the ion sources were set at 19 and 16.7kV for ion sources 1 and 2, respectively, while the lens was set at 8.50kV. The reflectors 1 and 2 voltages were set at 21 and 9.7kV respectively. The spectra were acquired using 2,5-dihydroxybenzoic acid as the MALDI matrix, using a 337nm nitrogen laser. Gel permeation chromatography (GPC) was performed using a Hewlett–Packard 1100 series chromatograph and this setup was previously successfully employed [22] (Hewlett Packard, Waldbronn, Germany). The chromatograph was interfaced with a DAWN DSP multi-angle laser light scattering (MALLS) (Wyatt Corp., Santa Barbara, CA) and refractive index (RI) detector for absolute molecular weight determination. Samples were prepared at ∼20mg/mL of which 100μL was injected onto the GPC columns. Isocratic conditions were used with distilled THF as eluent at a flow rate of 1mL/min and a 0.5μm inline filter preceded connection of the pump to a series of GPC columns that covered a wide molecular weight range to ensure resolution (Agilent PLgel™ 10μm with pore size 105 Å, Agilent PLgel MIXED-C™ and a Phenomenex Phenogel™ 5μm with a pore size of 100Å). The specific refractive increment dn/dc was determined online as previously described in literature and was determined at 0.077±0.002 for the samples reported here. The number average molecular weight ( M ¯ n ), weight average molecular weight ( M ¯ w ) and polydispersity index (PDI) were calculated using ASTRA™ 4.73 (Wyatt Corp., Santa Barbara). Sample solutions were filtered via a syringe through 0.45μm PTFE syringe filters before being subjected to analysis. Found: C, 58.01; H, 4.96; N, 6.67%. 2.3 General procedure for ring open polymerization of ϵ-caprolactone Solvent free method: ϵ-CL (1.14g, 0.01mol) and the required amount of zinc complex, depending on the ratio of [monomer]:[complex] ([CL]/[C]) used, were weighed into a Radley's parallel reactor tube and stirred at 110°C. The polymerization of ϵ-CL was carried out in bulk with [CL]/[C] ratios of 100:1, 200:1 400:1 and 800:1. After the required reaction time, the reaction mixture was quenched by rapid cooling to room temperature and the crude product was analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopy in CDCl3. The percentage conversion of ϵ-CL into PCL was determined from the proton intensities of the methylene protons of ϵ-CL and PCL that appear in the region 4.2-4.0ppm. The polymers were purified by first dissolving the crude product in CH2Cl2, followed by the addition of cold methanol. A white precipitate was subsequently formed, and this was isolated by filtration and dried in vacuo. The number of repeat units in the purified PCL samples was determined by 1H NMR spectrum from the ratio of the proton intensities of C H 2O of the PCL (δ (ppm)=4.019−4.053ppm) main chain and C H 2OH as end group (δ (ppm)=3.611−3.644). 2.4 Electrochemical analysis of polymers The electrochemical cell use for the analysis consists of a three-electrode cell, namely a glassy carbon working electrode (geometric area=0.071cm2), a Ag/AgCl (3M KCl) reference electrode, and a platinum wire as the counter electrode. The measurements were performed using concentrations of samples 1.0mM, in the presence of 0.1M tetra-n-ethylammonium perchlorate (supporting electrolyte) in dry acetonitrile under argon atmosphere at room temperature. The glassy carbon electrode was polished on a Buehler-felt pad using alumina (0.05μm) and then washed with millipore water, sonicated for 5min in millipore water and finally rinsed with a buffer solution at pH 9.2. This was performed to ensure that there were no contaminants on the electrode surface before the electrochemical measurements. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Syntheses of ligands and complexes Compounds L1-L4 were synthesized as reported in literature [19,20]. These compounds were used as ligands to synthesize the zinc complexes 1-4 in a 1:1 ratio between zinc acetate and the respective ligands as shown in Schemes 1 and 2 , . The zinc complexes were obtained as orange solids after recrystallization in CH2Cl2 and diethyl ether with yields between 84 and 90%. All complexes are stable in air and no special pre-cautions were taken in their storage. 1H NMR spectra of the zinc complexes showed significant shifts downfield compared to their corresponding ligands as well as the presence of methyl proton signals from the acetate which appeared between 1.95ppm and 2.03ppm. Furthermore, the structural isomerism observed in the ligands was also found in the zinc complexes. A typical spectrum is that of complex 1 (Fig. S1). IR spectra of the complexes 1-4 show the presence of sharp carbonyl stretching frequencies between 1600 and 1625cm−1. These frequencies are higher compared to the carbonyl of the acetate in the zinc precursor which appears at 1547cm−1. Mass spectra of 1-4 showed 100% m/z of [M+H]+, which indicate the presence of the expected zinc complexes. Elemental analyses of the zinc complexes were consistent with the structures proposed in Schemes 1 and 2, and also confirm the purity of the (ferrocenylpyrazoly)zinc(II) acetate complexes. In solution there were strong indications that all four zinc complexes undergo some isomerization; although we were unable to isolate any of the structural isomers. This isomerization could be monitored by 1H NMR spectroscopy. For example freshly prepared sample of 4 (Fig. S2) showed a 1H NMR spectrum where the CH3 protons of acetate group integrate for 6 protons at 1.95ppm, to indicate binding of two acetate ligands. Also there is one peak which represents the pyrazolyl proton at 6.17ppm. After 1h in solution (Fig. S3) the spectrum of complex 4 the integration of the proton of the acetate group has increased to approximately 9 protons; and there were two proton peaks at 6.17ppm and 6.18ppm representing pyrazolyl protons. After 2h, the intensities of the new peaks increased (Fig. S4) and by 5h there was no further increase in the intensities of the new peaks, suggesting equilibrium had been reached in the isomerization process. Attempts to grow crystals of either isomer were unsuccessful as prolonged stay in solution (ca. 4 weeks) invariably resulted in the decomposition of the complexes and only crystals of ferrocenylpyrazolyl ligands were obtained. 3.2 Catalysis 3.2.1 Solvent free ring-opening polymerization of ϵ-caprolactone Initial polymerization studies of ϵ-caprolactone (ϵ-CL) were conducted at 110°C using the complexes 1-4 with a monomer to complex ratio of 100:1 without a solvent. Table 1 (entries 1, 4, 7 and 10) show that all the zinc complexes catalyzed the ring-opening polymerization (ROP) of ϵ-CL with different activities. Complex 4 was found to be the most active while complex 2 was the least active. The molecular weight (M n) and polydispersity indices (PDI) of the purified polymers were determined by GPC. Varying the monomer to complex ratio from 100 to 800 did not result in significant changes in the molecular weight and the PDIs of the polymers produced with complexes 1 and 2 (Table 2 , entries 1–6). For complexes 3 and 4, a decrease in molecular weight of the polymers was observed (Table 2, entries 7–12) and only slight variations were observed in the PDIs as the monomer to zinc complex ratio was increased. It is noteworthy that all the GPC traces showed monomodal distribution. Ojwach et al. [23] have recently reported zinc and copper acetate complexes supported by (pyrazol-1-ylmethyl)pyridine as catalysts for the ring-opening polymerization of ϵ-CL. Having a ferrocenyl instead of methyl group on the pyrazole increases the rate of reaction comparing the zinc complexes for the Ojwach catalysts and ours. For instance, Ojwach et al. reported that 94% conversion in 48h for their zinc catalysts whereas complex 2 showed 88% conversion in 22h (Table 1, entry 4) under similar conditions. In addition, our reported PDI for the PCL from complex 2 is 1.20 (Table 1, entry 4) compared to 3.23 reported by Ojwach et al. The lower PDI value can be attributed to the shorter reaction time thus less transesterification reactions. We obtained molecular weights (2900gmol−1) that are comparable to those obtained by Ojwach et al., therefore the overall effect of having ferrocenyl group instead of methyl group on the pyrazole appears to produce the right electrophilicity of the zinc centre thus resulting in a more active catalyst. Analogous (ferrocenylpyrazolyl)zinc(II) benzoates have been recently reported as catalysts for the ring opening polymerization of ϵ-CL [20]. The only difference between these zinc benzoate complexes and current one lies in the acetate. Comparison of the activities of complexes 1-4 to those of the zinc benzoates complexes reported in the literature [20] show that the acetates have better activity. For example, the (ferrocenylpyrazolyl)zinc(II) benzoates [20] required 20–69h to reach 90% conversion whereas the acetate complexes needed only 12–22h to attain similar conversions for (Table 1). Furthermore, the PCL samples from the zinc acetate complexes showed lower PDI (1.12–1.84) compared to the zinc benzoate complexes (1.20–9.57) [20]. MALDI-TOF MS was used to further characterize the PCLs obtained with all the zinc complexes. Typical MALDI-TOF MS spectra of PCL obtained with complex 1 ([CL]/[C]=100) are shown in Fig. 1 and Fig. S5. The MALDI-TOF MS data confirms that there is only one species, that is, a α,ω-dihydroxy-PCL; suggesting that no ligands from that zinc complex capped the polymer. Furthermore, the α,ω-dihydroxy-PCL were also observed in the MALDI-TOF mass spectra of the PCL obtained from complex 2 ([CL]/[C]=100) and varying the [CL]/[C] for complexes 1 and 2 showed the same PCL species. Conversely, MALDI-TOF MS for the purified PCL from complex 4 ([CL]/[C]=100) showed that there are two PCL species (Fig. 2 and Fig. S6). The major PCL species has the ferrocenyl-pyrazolyl-ethylamino and a hydroxyl as end groups and while a minor species with α,ω-dihydroxy-end group in PCL was identified, which suggests that there are two modes of initiation using complex 4. The MALDI-TOF mass spectra of the PCL samples from complex 3 ([CL]/[C]=100) showed similar PCL composition as found for complex 4. Varying the [CL]/[C] ratio from 100 to 800 for complexes 3 and 4 did not change the composition of the PCL. There was no evidence in the MALDI-TOF analysis for the formation of cyclic products in the ring opening polymerization; suggesting that there were no transesterification reactions. 1H NMR spectra also confirmed the presence of (ferrocenylpyrazolyl) ethylamino end group PCL from complexes 3 and 4. A typical PCL spectrum showing signals for t ligand L2 in the region 6.0–6.1ppm for the pyrazolyl proton and 4.0–4.6ppm for the ferrocenyl protons is Fig. S7. No signals were, however, observed in the same regions for the PCL obtained from complexes 1 and 2. To further confirm the presence of the (ferrocenylpyrazolyl)ethylamino end group, two further experiments, namely cyclic voltammetry and Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) were performed on the PCLs obtained with complexes 1-4. The presence of the ferrocenyl moiety in the PCL samples shows quasi-reversible one electron redox potential, evident in the ΔE values between 130 and 141mV. A typical voltammogram is shown in Fig. S8 for PCL produced with complex 3 ([CL]/[C]=100) with redox potential of 141mV. This redox potential is high compared to that of the free ligand (L3) which is 87.0mV [24]. The Energy Dispersive X-ray (EDX) result, which is a qualitative analysis, shows the presence of the Fe atom in the ferrocenyl unit and oxygen which forms the backbone of the polymer. There was no evidence of zinc present in the polymer for this analysis, indicative of the purity of the polymer. A typical spectrum of a PCL sample from complex 3 is Fig. S9a thus confirming the incorporation of ligand L3 in the polymer. Fig. S9b shows the EDX result of PCL synthesized with complex 2. The figure also confirms the result obtained from the MALDI-TOF MS that there is no ligand end group for polymers obtained with complex 2. Having two modes of initiation for complexes 3 and 4 is not surprising because a primary amine is known to initiate the ring-opening polymerization of ϵ-CL in the presence of a Lewis acid such as stannous 2-ethylhexnoate (Sn(Oct)2) [25]. The initiation step is similar to when alcohol is used as a co-initiator in conjunction with Sn(Oct)2 as catalyst. A plausible reason for dual initiation modes of complexes 3 and 4 is that the amine-zinc bond is weak enough to allow insertion. This is further confirmed by the complexes not being very stable in solution. The complexes eventually decompose to form the corresponding ligand and zinc acetate (vide supra). However, this phenomenon was not observed in the analogous (ferrocenylpyrazolyl)zinc(II) benzoates, suggesting that the latter zinc complexes are much more stable than the zinc acetate complexes [20]. It is noteworthy that there is no ϵ-CL insertion in complexes 1 and 2, as the pyridyl nitrogen is a stronger σ–donor and thus binds more strongly. The kinetics of the ϵ-CL bulk ROP were investigated for complexes 1-4 by monitoring the reactions using 1H NMR spectroscopy. Sampling was performed at regular time intervals and the percentages conversions of ϵ-CL to PCL were determined. The rate of propagation (R p) for the ring-opening polymerization of cyclic esters at a given temperature is given by; R P = − d [ M ] t dt = K P [ I ] o [ M ] t The pseudo-first order kinetics with respect to the monomer for ring-opening polymerization is defined by the following equation where [M]o is the initial monomer concentration, [M]t is the monomer concentration at time t, and [I]o is the initial initiator concentration. ln ( [ M ] o [ M ] t ) = K P I o t For a given M/I value, the [I]o is constant and thus k p[I]o is substituted by k app to give the following equation. ln ( [ M ] o [ M ] t ) = K app t From the plot of ln([M]o/[M]t) versus time, the values of k app are obtained and k p can be obtained from a plot of k app (1/t ln([M]o/[M] t )) against [I]o, assuming a first order reaction with respect to the initiator or catalyst. The kinetics investigation with 1-4 (Figs. 3, S10, S11, and Fig. 4 ) revealed the polymerization was pseudo-first order with respect to ϵ-CL for all zinc complexes. The induction period observed for complexes 1 and 2 is attributed to the formation of the active species between the zinc complex and the trace amount of water in the complexes since MALDI-TOF MS data shows formation of α,ω-dihydroxy-PCL. Similar observations were made for analogous (ferrocenylpyrazolyl)zinc(II) benzoates complexes [20]. The order of the reaction with respect to complexes 1-4 and the overall rate of polymerization also were determined. A plot of 1/t ln[CL]o/[CL]t (k app) against number of moles of complex gave a linear relationship; consistent with a pseudo first order dependency with respect to the complexes (Fig. 5 ). Similar observations were made for zinc carboxylate with pyrazolyl ligands [20,23]. For complexes 4 and 1, the overall rate constants of polymerization (k p) were evaluated to be 2.17×10−7 and 1.06×10−7 h−1 mol−1 respectively (Fig. 5). It is notable that complexes 1 and 4 show the highest k p values in the two types of ancillary ligands system investigated in this report. This accounts for their high catalytic activities. The k app and k p values for the remaining complexes are summarized in Table S1. From the kinetic studies, the activities of the complexes can be arranged in the order of 4 > 1 > 2 > 3. Since complexes 1 and 2 have a different mode of initiation compared to complexes 3 and 4, the catalytic activities have to be explained within each set of ligand system. In considering the pyridyl based ligands, complex 1 was found to be more active than complex 2 and this feature can be explained by both electronic and steric factors. In terms of steric factor, ϵ-CL should have less difficulty in approaching the metal centre of complexes 1 as there is less steric crowding and the extra methyl group on the pyrazole increases the electron density around the zinc center in complex 2 making it less electrophilic. In the case of amine based ligands, that is complexes 3 and 4, complex 4 was found to be more active than complex 3. The difference in activity of these complexes does not seem to be governed by electronic and steric factors but rather by the stability and solubility of the complexes as the initiation of the polymerization involves insertion of ϵ-CL into the zinc-nitrogen (amine) bond. From the stability studies, it was found that complex 3 is more stable than complex 4, thus a weaker zinc-nitrogen bond in the latter favors faster ϵ-CL insertion. The additional methyl group in complex 4 increases its solubility and thus more available for insertion. 3.2.2 ROP of caprolactone with complexes 1-4 and butan-1-ol Since complexes 1-2 gave only α,ω-dihydroxy-PCL, attempts to control the molecular weight by adding quantitative amounts of alcohol was also made. Experiments were conducted using butan-1-ol at [CL]/[nBuOH]=50 and [CL]/[C]=800. Shorter polymerization times were required under the aforementioned conditions, for instance, complex 1 in the presence of nBuOH, reached 77% conversion in 36h whereas only 69h were required to reach 88% conversion for complex 1. Furthermore, molecular weights of the PCL samples obtained, were similar or lower compared to those obtained in experiments without the addition of alcohol. MALDI-TOF MS showed bi-modal distributions suggesting that both water and butan-1-ol initiate ring-opening polymerization of ϵ-CL (Fig. S12). Polymerization was conducted with complexes 3 and 4 in the presence of nBuOH under the same conditions. Similar results were obtained as those obtained with complexes 1–2 suggesting that there is no ϵ-CL in the zinc-amine bond in the presence of nBuOH (Fig. S13). 3.2.3 Solution ring-opening polymerization of ϵ-caprolactone with complexes 1–4 Solution polymerization of ϵ-CL was performed in toluene at monomer concentration 1M and 2M using complexes 1–4 (Table 2) to investigate whether the transesterification reactions that were observed in the solvent free method causing low molecular weights can be suppressed. The trend in the catalytic activity in the presence of toluene as solvent (1M) was identical to what was observed in the bulk process that is, 4 > 1 > 2 > 3 at the same [CL]/[C] ratio. From the GPC results, it can be deduced that higher molecular weights can be obtained from solution ring-opening polymerization compared to the solvent free experiments. A plausible explanation is that in solution ring-opening polymerization, the system is dilute and the growing polymer chain stays away from the active center thus reducing side reactions. The polydispersity indices recorded for the solution polymerization ranged from 1.36 to 1.54 which is almost the same as recorded for complexes 3 and 4 in the solvent free method however complexes 1 and 2 showed lower PDIs. From complex 1 to 4 (Table 2), the trend observed in the molecular weight is the reverse when compared to bulk polymerization. In bulk polymerization it was complex 4 that gave the highest molecular weight whereas complex 1 that gave the lowest molecular weight. The reverse was observed for solution polymerization. The time required to achieve high conversion is considerably lower in the solvent free experiment compared to the results shown in Table 2. For example, with complex 4 in the solvent free method, 12h were required to reach 97% conversion whereas with toluene at 1M monomer concentration, 22h were needed to reach a similar conversion (Table 2, entry 4). In addition solution polymerization in toluene at 2M monomer concentration was slightly faster than 1M monomer concentration. For example, for complex 4, 100% conversion was obtained in 21h for 2M, whereas 97% conversion was obtained in 22h for 1M. Kinetic studies (Fig. S14 and S15) were also performed and results indicate that only complex 4 showed a significant change in the k app compared to the bulk experiment. 4 Conclusions A series of (ferrocenylpyrazolyl)zinc(II) acetate complexes were synthesized, characterized and used for ring-opening polymerization of ϵ-caprolactone. All complexes were found to be active for the ring-opening polymerization of ϵ-caprolactone. Complexes 1 and 2 acted as catalysts whilst 3 and 4 acted as initiators. There was monomer insertion in the zinc-amine bond in relation to complexes 3 and 4 in the initiation step whereas complex 1 and 2 behave as catalysts. The PCL produced using complexes 1 and 2 mainly had α,ω-dihydroxy end groups while those of complexes 3 and 4 were ferrocenylpyrazolylamine capped. Solution polymerization in toluene gave better molecular weight polymers than the solvent free method. coredata.dc:description: The reaction of Zn(OAc)2 with 3-ferrocenylpyrazol-1-ylmethylenepyridine (L1), 3-ferrocenyl-5-methylpyrazol-1-ylmethylenepyridine (L2), 3-ferrocenylpyrazol-1-ylethylamine (L3) and 3-ferrocenyl-5-pyrazol-1-ylethylamine (L4) afford the corresponding zinc complexes [Zn(CH3COO)2(L1)] (1), [Zn(CH3COO)2(L2)] (2), [Zn(CH3COO)2(L3)] (3), and [Zn(CH3COO)2(L4)] (4). These zinc complexes behave as catalysts or initiators for the ring opening polymerization of ϵ-caprolactone, depending on the nature of the ligands, to produce polymers that are capped with α,ω-dihydroxy, hydroxyl or ferrocenylpyrazolylethylamino end groups. Complexes 1 and 2 were found to act as catalysts when the [CL]/[C] ratios were varied from 100 to 800 to produce PCL with α,ω-dihydroxy and nearly the same molecular weight. Complexes 3 and 4 on the other hand act as initiators to produce a mixture of PCL that have polymers with ferrocenylpyrazolylethylamino and a hydroxyl as end groups as the major component of the mixture and minor species with α,ω-dihydroxy end group.
coredata.dc:title: (Ferrocenylpyrazolyl)zinc(II) acetate complexes as initiators and catalysts for the ring opening polymerization of ϵ-caprolacton.
